> I'm not completely seeing the importance of
> processing time for 
> network activation as a statistic for comparison. 
> I'm not even sure 
> that the activation method should be considered
> NEAT-specific.  You 
> can use any activation method you want with a NEAT
> network.

That is true, and could be useful if the method in
NEAT was slow for some application.  One could take
the topology and weights that were evolved, and then
write code to implement it in a speedy manner.
 
> > For example, is NEAT fast enough to use a
> NEAT-evolved
> > network in a real time application?
> > 
> 
> The NN activations generally don't take up
> significant computation 
> time.  We can run 50 networks at the same time in
> real-time easily 
> on a single processor.  Obviously at some huge
> network size things 
> will start slowing down, but then again, what else
> can you do if a 
> huge network is necessary to solve the task?
> 
> Anyway, I think most interesting domains assume
> their cost mostly 
> from domain simulation and not network activation.

It's probably true that for most applications, the
application-specific code probably takes longer than
processing the NEAT net, but we can't be sure that's
true until someone measures the latter.

=====
Mitchell Timin
